dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and before she was 18, she was married with a child, never left her village. And, um, this isn't an isolated incident, is it? It's repeated millions of times.

dialogue_turns.text: No, it's not. Over 130 million girls worldwide are out of school through no fault of their own. And for many African girls, their fate is, like, already determined by the time they turn ten.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's where foundations like the Joyce Banda Foundation come in, aiming to strengthen the financial independence of Malawian women. And, uh, create conditions for young girls to emerge as future leaders.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And we are seeing some positive shifts, aren't we? Like, in parts of Africa, nearly a quarter of Sub-Saharan Africa's lawmakers are women now, up from just 10% in '97. Rwanda even has the highest percentage globally.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's really encouraging progress. But, um, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation's upcoming Goalkeepers report will probably make it clear that a lot of work still remains.

dialogue_turns.text: Joyce Banda, herself, having been president, became convinced that the only way to change Africa's misogynistic narrative is by helping more women reach the highest levels of power.
